results.title: The Texas chain saw massacre (D)
results.brief_description: Loosely based on the grizzly exploits of American serial killer Ed Gein (also a model for Norman Bates in “Psycho”), Tobe Hooper’s “The Texas chain saw massacre” rightly deserves its place as a horror classic. Five teenagers travelling through Texas (two of them brother and sister investigating the mysterious desecration of their grandfather’s grave), pick up a creepy hitchhiker and find themselves embroiled in a macabre and nightmarish reverse of southern hospitality. From its eerie opening images to its shocking finale, “The Texas chain saw massacre’ was initially considered a cheap drive-in exploitation film but, through strong critical appraisal, went on to be screened as part of the director’s fortnight at Cannes and the American Museum of Modern Art now has a print of it in its permanent collection. Cast includes Marilyn Burns, Allen Danziger and Gunnar Hansen as Leatherface.

results.title: The Terror. Ghosts on the loose
results.creator_credit: William Beaudine, Jack Nicholson, Monte Hellman, Francis Ford Coppola, Roger Corman, Sam Katzman, Jack Dietz, Monogram Pictures Corporation and Filmgroup
results.brief_description: Monogram studios were one of the leading B-Grade film studios in Hollywood, putting out a collection of gangster, thriller and horror films that were commercially successful and ignored by American critics. It wasn’t till after World War II, when European critics started writing of their love for B-grade Hollywood cinema that many of the films gained the attention they deserved. Roger Corman has himself built a singular reputation as one of the B-grade cinema’s luminaries, having developed an oeuvre of cheap exploitation work that also allows talented young directors to get their first breaks in the motion picture industry. “Ghosts on the loose” is a cheap Monogram horror spoof that takes great delight in lampooning Bela Lugosi and Ava Gardners’ screen images. The East End Kids star as a group of youths daring each other to enter a ghost house. Roger Corman’s “The Terror” has a young Jack Nicholson playing a weary soldier of the Napoleonic Wars who enters a strange land of witchcraft and menace, ruled over by a mad Baron played by Boris Karloff. Francis Ford Coppola assisted in the direction of “The Terror” as did Nicholson and an uncredited Monte Hellman.

results.title: VFX in The Umbrella Academy
results.credit_line:
VFX Supervisor: Chris White
Courtesy Weta Digital and Netflix
results.brief_description: A look at how Weta Digital made Pogo in The Umbrella Academy.

constellations_primary.name: MoCaps and rotos
constellations_primary.description: Though VFX continues to push boundaries and brings fantastical worlds and creatures to life, there's still a place for classic animation techniques.

results.description: “Nietzsche once said ‘Man is as a rope stretched between the animal and the superhuman’,” muses Sir Reginald Hargreeves in the first episode of Umbrella Academy (2019). It’s an ironic line, given the most human character in the Netflix original series is not human at all, but rather a being who personifies the middle ground between the animal and the superhuman. There are few places better suited to delicately walking that line than Weta Digital, with the New Zealand-based digital visual effects company creating the character of Pogo. Think Batman’s butler but, well, a chimpanzee. Guardian to the dysfunctional Hargreeves family of superheroes, actor Ken Hall’s movements on set became a visual reference for Weta animators, combined with the facial and vocal performance of Adam Godley in the studio.
description_for_label: “Nietzsche once said ‘Man is as a rope stretched between the animal and the superhuman’,” muses Sir Reginald Hargreeves in the Umbrella Academy. It’s ironic, given the most human character in the show isn’t human but a being who bridges the animal and the superhuman. New Zealand-based VFX studio Weta Digital drew on past experience rendering CGI apes to bring Pogo to life. Think Batman’s butler but a chimpanzee, which Weta made by combining Ken Hall’s on-set movements and Adam Godley’s facial and vocal performance.

results.title: The Terror
results.brief_description: Shipwrecked Lieutenant Andre Duvalier (Jack Nicholson) stumbles across a beautiful woman on the beach who calls herself Helene. Later, no one claims to have ever seen her and just as mysteriously as she appeared, she disappears into the sea. He travels to the Castle of Baron Von Leppe where he meets Frederick Von Leppe (Boris Karloff), who informs Duvalier that Helene was his wife, the Baroness Von Leppe who has been dead for 20 years. It’s revealed that Helene is acting in obeyance to an old witch intent on revenge against the Baron and only Andre can free her from the spell. This was the third collaboration between Jack Nicholson and Roger Corman (Little shop of horrors, The Raven), the first with Nicholson in the lead role and features the usual Corman tenets of a busty female lead, skeletons in the closet and cut price special effects. A touch of “The Birds” is evident, with birds circling ominously and providing a tangible link between the witch and her puppet Helene. Cast includes: Sandra Knight, Richard Miller, Dorothy Neumann.

results.title: The Terror of Tiny Town
results.creator_credit: Sam Newfield, Jed Buell, Bert Sternbach, Abe Meyer, Principal Productions and Columbia Pictures Corporation
results.brief_description: This movie has all the classic elements usually found in westerns of the 1930’s - 1950’s. The dashing hero, the fair damsel in need of rescuing, the despised villain, singing, dancing, and the big chase scene. It’s all here. The one thing that separates this movie from any other western is the cast. 100% midgets, the entire movie is cast with actors under the height of 4 feet 8 inches, with a couple of fellas who just might make three feet. You haven’t seen a true chase scene until you see a group of guys chasing each other on Shetland ponies.

results.title: Very bad things
results.creator_credit: Peter Berg, Diane Nabatoff, Michael Schiffer, Cindy Cowan, Ballpark Productions, Interscope Communication and Initial Entertainment Group (US)
results.brief_description: Very bad things is a very grim tale of morality and the bond between killers. Kyle Fisher is about to marry Laura, a neurotic, insecure woman, whose wedding plans are being administered by her in a caustic, shrill manner. Kyle’s four best friends - Adam, Michael, Charles and Robert - decide to take him to Vegas for the bucks turn, complete with drugs, booze and strippers. On the night in question one man accidentally kills a prostitute. Encouraged by Robert (Christian Slater) the group decide to bury the body in the desert. Before they can do this however a security guard discovers their crime and is promptly dispatched of also. With two bodies to dispose of the men are drawn into a gruesome pact that will assuredly be their undoing. Upon their return home the friends exchange increasingly bitter and acrimonious accusations as they attempt to deal with their misdeeds. Cameron Diaz plays Laura - the bride who will stop at nothing to have her wedding day perfect, disguising the moral degradation of those around her. Peter Berg makes his directorial debut with this very dark comedy that evokes the spirit of Tarantino, the Coen bothers and Danny Boyle. Also stars: Jeanne Tripplehorn, Daniel Stern and Jon Favreau.
